results.title: Ali Baba
results.brief_description: An animated film presenting the tale of the little boy and the forty thieves with charmingly designed and coloured figures. Ali Baba’s discovery of the hidden treasure, how he keeps Mustafa and the thieves from recapturing it, and the lad’s generosity as he distributes the jewels among the townspeople is told with brief rhymed narration to the accompaniment of wind music. No other credits available.

results.title: Algerian pipeline
results.creator_credit: Derek Williams, Humphrey Swingler, British Information Services and Greenpark Productions
results.brief_description: The ever-increasing output of Algeria’s oilfields demanded a new pipeline outlet to the Mediterranean. The sponsors were awarded a 25 million pound contract to design and construct a complete pipeline installation within the short time of 18 months. This film describes how a 500-mile pipeline was constructed from the Sahara across the Atlas Mountains to Arzew. The building of pump stations, departure and arrival terminals, submarine loading lines, ancillary works and the training of Algerian personnel are also covered.

results.title: Albert Speer: the last nazi
results.creator_credit: Brian Nolan, W.R. Callaghan, Global Television Network and Lakeville Group
results.brief_description: Several years after his release from Spandau prison, where he completed his twenty-year sentence for war crimes, Albert Speer is interviewed by Canadian reporter Patrick Watson. The interview reveals Speer’s assessment of his life, and chronicles the rise and fall of the Nazi regime, shedding light on the behaviour of a great many Germans who fell under Hitler’s spell. Valuable documentary footage, including some of Speer’s home movies.

results.title: Alfred Hitchcock
results.brief_description: This program presents Alfred Hitchcock, the master of suspense, in a rare discussion of his film-making techniques and his illustrious 50 year career as a director. Filled with classic film clips, the program reveals that Hitchcock’s famous cinematic techniques for instilling suspense and terror were the result of his detailed planning of each scene at the script stage. Hitchcock’s career is reviewed with the use of selected film clips from his most famous movies and through the recollections of the stars who worked with him. Included are excerpts from “Psycho” with Anthony Perkins and Janet Leigh, “North by North West” with Cary Grant, and “Frenzy” with Jon Finch and Barry Foster.

results.title: Alfie
results.creator_credit: Lewis Gilbert and Sheldrake Films Ltd
results.brief_description: This wonderful comedy is the film that catapulted Michael Caine to stardom. Alfie (Caine) is not really a bad sort. He’s just a philandering cockney playboy who has this overwhelming desire for the opposite sex. What’s more, he likes to brag about his conquests, and he doesn’t have to exaggerate, because Alfie gets them all; fat, thin, blonde, brunette, young and even the older ‘richer’ woman. He’s just irresistible, no one can beat him at the mating game! This is Michael Caine at his chauvinistic best. Also stars Shelly Winters as Ruby. Based on the play by Bill Naughton.

results.title: Alex the talking chimp
results.brief_description: This is a story about Sidney Martin’s Carnival, a small-time carnival in small-town America. Sidney’s carnival is going through bad times and a feud between Kirk the Animal Trainer and Markov the Magnificent over Kirk’s inhumane treatment of the animals doesn’t make things any easier. Markov is fired, but unbeknownst to Sidney and the rest of the carnival workers, Markov has a secret weapon in the form of a talking chimp called Alex. Can Alex save the day? Will Markov, who is totally against the exploitation of animals, let Alex perform alongside him in order to keep his job? Experience the magic of a carnival and see what it’s like behind the scenes - the people, the relationships, the problems, the good times and the bad times. Cast includes Jennifer Houlton, Howard Segal, Mark Weston and Trudi the chimp.

results.title: Akira. Akira: production report
results.brief_description: This two volume collector’s edition contains the film itself and a 49 minute long report on the making of “Akira” featuring interviews with the director, the techniques he used and character profiles. “Akira” is set in 2019 in the city of Neo-Tokyo which is about to explode. A group of motorcycle-riding teenagers living in Neo-Tokyo tries to stop one of the gang who has run amok after becoming empowered with telekinetic powers in a government experiment. Technically spectacular, with colourful animation “Akira” is a must see for adult animation buffs.

results.title: Alcohol: how much is too much
results.creator_credit: Alan Capps, Frank Gardonyi, Ingvar Grimsgaard, Lou Lilly, Quartet Films and West
results.brief_description: An open-minded film which discusses social and physiological effects of alcohol. It is particularly designed for elementary grades. The film considers alcohol through such facts as its abuse as a drug, and its physiological effects on the brain and other parts of the human body. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alan Capps, Frank Gardonyi, Ingvar Grimsgaard, Lou Lilly, Quartet Films and West

results.title: Albert and David Maysles filming Big Edie and Little Edie in Grey Gardens
results.brief_description: Dziga Vertov’s kino-pravda (“film truth”) concept was premised on the camera’s ability to reveal truth. It inspired both cinéma vérité and direct cinema, which informed Albert and David Maysles’ intimate ‘fly-on-the-wall’ style and Agnès Varda’s intimate portraits of society and herself.
results.title_for_label: Albert and David Maysles filming Big Edie and Little Edie in Grey Gardens
results.description: Documentarians develop camera techniques to access, interpret and compose notions of truth. Dziga Vertov’s kino-pravda (“film truth”) concept was premised on the camera’s ability to reveal truth. In the 1960s, it inspired the development of both cinéma vérité (“truthful cinema”) and direct cinema, which informed Albert and David Maysles’ intimate ‘fly-on-the-wall’ style and Agnès Varda’s use of a handheld camera to create a portrait of society and herself.
description_for_label: Documentarians develop camera techniques to access, interpret and compose notions of truth. Dziga Vertov’s kino-pravda (“film truth”) concept was premised on the camera’s ability to reveal truth. In the 1960s, it inspired the development of both cinéma vérité (“truthful cinema”) and direct cinema, which informed Albert and David Maysles’ intimate ‘fly-on-the-wall’ style and Agnès Varda’s use of a handheld camera to create a portrait of society and herself.

results.title: Alcohol in the human body
results.creator_credit: Felix Forsman and Fennada Filmi Junior
results.brief_description: A cartoon showing the impact of alcohol on the nervous system. It portrays sensibly, objectively and lucidly all effects of alcohol in the human body, and the problems these pose in our society. It leaves the viewer to draw his own conclusions.
